an10.139:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the defiled principle and the undefiled. …

an10.139:1.3.eng: And what is the defiled principle?

an10.139:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.139:1.5.eng: This is called the defiled principle.

an10.139:1.6.eng: And what is the undefiled principle?

an10.139:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.139:1.8.eng: This is called the undefiled principle.”

an10.14:1.1.pli: “Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā pañca cetokhilā appahīnā pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no vuddhi.
an10.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a monk or nun who has not given up five kinds of hard-heartedness and has not severed five shackles of the heart can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

an10.14:2.1.eng: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up?

an10.14:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
an10.14:2.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

an10.14:2.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:2.3.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:2.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo appahīno hoti.
an10.14:2.4.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

an10.14:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati …pe…
an10.14:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

an10.14:3.4.pli: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto.
an10.14:3.4.eng: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

an10.14:3.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:3.5.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:3.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo appahīno hoti.
an10.14:3.6.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

an10.14:3.7.eng: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they haven’t given up.

an10.14:4.1.eng: What are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed?

an10.14:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
an10.14:4.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

an10.14:4.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:4.3.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:4.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetasovinibandho asamucchinno hoti.
an10.14:4.4.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.

an10.14:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye avītarāgo hoti …pe…
an10.14:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …

an10.14:5.2.eng: They’re not free of greed for form …

an10.14:5.3.pli: yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati …
an10.14:5.3.eng: They eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

an10.14:5.4.pli: aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
an10.14:5.4.eng: They lead the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

an10.14:5.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:5.5.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:5.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetasovinibandho asamucchinno hoti.
an10.14:5.6.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they haven’t severed.

an10.14:5.7.eng: These are the five shackles of the heart they haven’t severed.

an10.14:6.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā ime pañca cetokhilā appahīnā ime pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no vuddhi.
an10.14:6.1.eng: A monk or nun who has not given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and has not severed these five shackles of the heart can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

an10.14:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kāḷapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, hāyateva vaṇṇena hāyati maṇḍalena hāyati ābhāya hāyati ārohapariṇāhena;
an10.14:7.1.eng: It’s like the moon in the waning fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, luminosity, and diameter and circumference only decline.

an10.14:7.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā ime pañca cetokhilā appahīnā ime pañca cetasovinibandhā asamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati hāniyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no vuddhi.
an10.14:7.2.eng: In the same way, monk or nun who has not given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and has not severed these five shackles of the heart can expect decline, not growth, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

an10.14:8.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā pañca cetokhilā pahīnā pañca cetasovinibandhā susamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no parihāni.
an10.14:8.1.eng: A monk or nun who has given up five kinds of hard-heartedness and has severed five shackles of the heart can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

an10.14:9.1.eng: What are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up?

an10.14:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati, adhimuccati sampasīdati.
an10.14:9.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has no doubts about the Teacher. They’re not uncertain, undecided, or lacking confidence.

an10.14:9.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satthari na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati adhimuccati sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:9.3.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:9.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo pahīno hoti.
an10.14:9.4.eng: This is the first kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

an10.14:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhamme na kaṅkhati …pe…
an10.14:10.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has no doubts about the teaching …

an10.14:10.4.pli: sabrahmacārīsu na kupito hoti attamano na āhatacitto na khilajāto.
an10.14:10.4.eng: A mendicant is not angry and upset with their spiritual companions, not resentful or closed off.

an10.14:10.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu na kupito hoti attamano na āhatacitto na khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:10.5.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:10.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo pahīno hoti.
an10.14:10.6.eng: This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

an10.14:10.7.eng: These are the five kinds of hard-heartedness they’ve given up.

an10.14:11.1.eng: What are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed?

an10.14:11.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho.
an10.14:11.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

an10.14:11.3.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmesu vītarāgo hoti vigatacchando vigatapemo vigatapipāso vigatapariḷāho vigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:11.3.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:11.4.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ paṭhamo cetasovinibandho susamucchinno hoti.
an10.14:11.4.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart they’ve severed.

an10.14:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye vītarāgo hoti …pe…
an10.14:12.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is rid of greed for the body …

an10.14:12.2.eng: They’re rid of greed for form …

an10.14:12.3.pli: na yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati,
an10.14:12.3.eng: They don’t eat as much as they like until their belly is full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

an10.14:12.4.pli: na aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
an10.14:12.4.eng: They don’t lead the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

an10.14:12.5.pli: Yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya …pe… devaññataro vāti, tassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
an10.14:12.5.eng: This being so, their mind inclines toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

an10.14:12.6.pli: Yassa cittaṃ namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, evamassāyaṃ pañcamo cetasovinibandho susamucchinno hoti.
an10.14:12.6.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart they’ve severed.

an10.14:12.7.eng: These are the five shackles of the heart they’ve severed.

an10.14:13.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, bhikkhave, bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā ime pañca cetokhilā pahīnā ime pañca cetasovinibandhā susamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no parihāni.
an10.14:13.1.eng: A monk or nun who has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and has severed these five shackles of the heart can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.

an10.14:14.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, juṇhapakkhe candassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati, vaḍḍhateva vaṇṇena vaḍḍhati maṇḍalena vaḍḍhati ābhāya vaḍḍhati ārohapariṇāhena;
an10.14:14.1.eng: It’s like the moon in the waxing fortnight. Whether by day or by night, its beauty, roundness, luminosity, and diameter and circumference only grow.

an10.14:14.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā ime pañca cetokhilā pahīnā ime pañca cetasovinibandhā susamucchinnā, tassa yā ratti vā divaso vā āgacchati vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā kusalesu dhammesu no parihānī”ti.
an10.14:14.2.eng: In the same way, a monk or nun who has given up these five kinds of hard-heartedness and has severed these five shackles of the heart can expect growth, not decline, in skillful qualities, whether by day or by night.”

an10.140:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the blameworthy principle and the blameless principle. …

an10.140:1.3.eng: And what is the blameworthy principle?

an10.140:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.140:1.5.eng: This is called the blameworthy principle.

an10.140:1.6.eng: And what is the blameless principle?

an10.140:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.140:1.8.eng: This is called the blameless principle.”

an10.141:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the mortifying principle and the unmortifying. …

an10.141:1.3.eng: And what is the mortifying principle?

an10.141:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.141:1.5.eng: This is called the mortifying principle.

an10.141:1.6.eng: And what is the unmortifying principle?

an10.141:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.141:1.8.eng: This is called the unmortifying principle.”

an10.142:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that leads to accumulation and that which leads to dispersal. …

an10.142:1.3.eng: And what is the principle that leads to accumulation?

an10.142:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.142:1.5.eng: This is called the principle that leads to accumulation.

an10.142:1.6.eng: And what is the principle that leads to dispersal?

an10.142:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.142:1.8.eng: This is called the principle that leads to dispersal.”

an10.143:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that has suffering as outcome, and that which has happiness as outcome. …

an10.143:1.3.eng: And what is the principle whose outcome is suffering?

an10.143:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.143:1.5.eng: This is the principle whose outcome is suffering.

an10.143:1.6.eng: And what is the principle whose outcome is happiness?

an10.143:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.143:1.8.eng: This is the principle whose outcome is happiness.”

an10.144:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle that results in suffering and that which results in happiness. …

an10.144:1.3.eng: And what principle results in suffering?

an10.144:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.144:1.5.eng: This is called the principle that results in suffering.

an10.144:1.6.eng: And what principle results in happiness?

an10.144:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.144:1.8.eng: This is called the principle that results in happiness.”

an10.145:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the noble path and the ignoble path. …

an10.145:1.3.eng: And what is the ignoble path?

an10.145:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.145:1.5.eng: This is called the ignoble path.

an10.145:1.6.eng: And what is the noble path?

an10.145:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.145:1.8.eng: This is called the noble path.”

an10.146:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the dark path and the bright path. …

an10.146:1.3.eng: And what is the dark path?

an10.146:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.146:1.5.eng: This is called the dark path.

an10.146:1.6.eng: And what is the bright path?

an10.146:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.146:1.8.eng: This is called the bright path.”

an10.147:1.1.eng: “I will teach you what is the true teaching and what is not the true teaching. …

an10.147:1.3.eng: And what is not the true teaching?

an10.147:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.147:1.5.eng: This is called what is not the true teaching.

an10.147:1.6.eng: And what is the true teaching?

an10.147:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.147:1.8.eng: This is called the true teaching.”

an10.148:0.3.eng: The Teaching of the True Persons

an10.148:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the teaching of the true persons and the teaching of the untrue persons. …

an10.148:1.3.eng: And what is the teaching of the untrue persons?

an10.148:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.148:1.5.eng: This is the teaching of the untrue persons.

an10.148:1.6.eng: And what is the teaching of the true persons?

an10.148:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.148:1.8.eng: This is the teaching of the true persons.”

an10.149:1.1.pli: “Uppādetabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na uppādetabbañca.
an10.149:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to activate and the principle not to activate. …

an10.149:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na uppādetabbo dhammo?
an10.149:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to activate?

an10.149:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.149:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na uppādetabbo dhammo.
an10.149:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to activate.

an10.149:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to activate?

an10.149:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.149:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to activate.”

an10.15:1.1.pli: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññināsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho;
an10.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.

an10.15:1.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te appamādamūlakā appamādasamosaraṇā. Appamādo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati.
an10.15:1.2.eng: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence, and diligence is said to be the best of them.

an10.15:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici jaṅgalānaṃ pāṇānaṃ padajātāni, sabbāni tāni hatthipade samodhānaṃ gacchanti, hatthipadaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ mahantattena;
an10.15:2.1.eng: The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.

an10.15:2.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te appamādamūlakā appamādasamosaraṇā. Appamādo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati.
an10.15:2.2.eng: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence, and diligence is said to be the best of them.

an10.15:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo sabbā tā kūṭaṅgamā kūṭaninnā kūṭasamosaraṇā, kūṭo tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:3.1.eng: The rafters of a bungalow all lean to the peak, slope to the peak, and meet at the peak, so the peak is said to be the topmost of them all.

an10.15:3.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te appamādamūlakā appamādasamosaraṇā. Appamādo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati.
an10.15:3.2.eng: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence, and diligence is said to be the best of them.

an10.15:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci mūlagandhā, kāḷānusāriyaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:4.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant root, spikenard is said to be the best.

an10.15:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci sāragandhā, lohitacandanaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:5.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.

an10.15:6.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci pupphagandhā, vassikaṃ tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:6.1.eng: Of all kinds of fragrant flower, jasmine is said to be the best.

an10.15:7.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci khuddarājāno, sabbe te rañño cakkavattissa anuyantā bhavanti, rājā tesaṃ cakkavattī aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:7.1.eng: All lesser kings are vassals of a wheel-turning monarch, so the wheel-turning monarch is said to be the foremost of them all.

an10.15:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yā kāci tārakarūpānaṃ pabhā, sabbā tā candappabhāya kalaṃ nāgghanti soḷasiṃ, candappabhā tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:8.1.eng: The radiance of all the stars is not worth a sixteenth part of the moon’s radiance, so the moon’s radiance is said to be the best of them all.

an10.15:9.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṃ abbhussakkamāno sabbaṃ ākāsagataṃ tamagataṃ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca;
an10.15:9.1.eng: In the autumn the heavens are sunny and cloudless. And as the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, it shines and glows and radiates.

an10.15:10.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yā kāci mahānadiyo, seyyathidaṃ—gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, sabbā tā samuddaṅgamā samuddaninnā samuddapoṇā samuddapabbhārā, mahāsamuddo tāsaṃ aggamakkhāyati;
an10.15:10.1.eng: All the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—flow, slant, slope, and incline towards the ocean, and the ocean is said to be the greatest of them.

an10.15:10.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, ye keci kusalā dhammā, sabbe te appamādamūlakā appamādasamosaraṇā. Appamādo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyatī”ti.
an10.15:10.2.eng: In the same way, all skillful qualities are rooted in diligence and meet at diligence, and diligence is said to be the best of them.”

an10.150:1.1.pli: “Āsevitabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na āsevitabbañca.
an10.150:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to cultivate and the principle not to cultivate. …

an10.150:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na āsevitabbo dhammo?
an10.150:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to cultivate?

an10.150:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.150:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na āsevitabbo dhammo.
an10.150:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to cultivate.

an10.150:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to cultivate?

an10.150:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.150:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to cultivate.”

an10.151:1.1.pli: “Bhāvetabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na bhāvetabbañca.
an10.151:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to develop and the principle not to develop. …

an10.151:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na bhāvetabbo dhammo?
an10.151:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to develop?

an10.151:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.151:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na bhāvetabbo dhammo.
an10.151:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to develop.

an10.151:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to develop?

an10.151:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.151:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to develop.”

an10.152:1.1.pli: “Bahulīkātabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na bahulīkātabbañca.
an10.152:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to make much of and the principle not to make much of. …

an10.152:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na bahulīkātabbo dhammo?
an10.152:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to make much of?

an10.152:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.152:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na bahulīkātabbo dhammo.
an10.152:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to make much of.

an10.152:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to make much of?

an10.152:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.152:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to make much of.”

an10.153:1.1.pli: “Anussaritabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na anussaritabbañca.
an10.153:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to recollect and the principle not to recollect. …

an10.153:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na anussaritabbo dhammo?
an10.153:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to recollect?

an10.153:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.153:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na anussaritabbo dhammo.
an10.153:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to recollect.

an10.153:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to recollect?

an10.153:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.153:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to recollect.”

an10.154:1.1.pli: “Sacchikātabbañca vo, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desessāmi na sacchikātabbañca.
an10.154:1.1.eng: “I will teach you the principle to realize and the principle not to realize. …

an10.154:1.3.pli: katamo ca, bhikkhave, na sacchikātabbo dhammo?
an10.154:1.3.eng: And what is the principle not to realize?

an10.154:1.4.eng: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

an10.154:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, na sacchikātabbo dhammo.
an10.154:1.5.eng: This is called the principle not to realize.

an10.154:1.6.eng: And what is the principle to realize?

an10.154:1.7.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

an10.154:1.8.eng: This is called the principle to realize.”
